— But there’s a kicker: Facebook’s cybersecurity chief Nathaniel Gleicher confirmed just before midnight Tuesday that the action it took against 115 accounts on Facebook and Instagram a night prior was due to “concerns that they were linked to the Russia-based Internet Research Agency (IRA) and engaged in coordinated inauthentic behavior.” Gleicher added that the company blocked more Instagram accounts Tuesday after a website claiming to be tied to the IRA published a list of pages they created, though he did not specify how many.

— What tech was seeing: A Facebook spokesman told MT on Tuesday that the misinformation the company identified largely fell into “two buckets”: polling place hoaxes, including the rumor that U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement authorities were staking out voting locations in search of immigrants (which ICE directly refuted on social media); and posts with false voting information, including hoaxes that Democrats and Republicans vote on different days.

Divided Congress: What it means for tech

With help from John Hendel, Ashley Gold, Nancy Scola and Margaret Harding McGill

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Tech is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Technology subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

— A close race for Hurd, a top tech wonk on the Hill: Rep. Will Hurd (R), a former CIA agent who’s become a leading congressional voice on tech issues like federal IT and artificial intelligence, was declared a winner against Democratic challenger Gina Ortiz Jones by the Associated Press — but the wire service later rescinded the declaration, as the race remained too close to call as of early this morning.

Officials at the Department of Homeland Security said on a Tuesday afternoon press call that any digital misinformation circulating had been “rapidly addressed by the platforms.” DHS Undersecretary Chris Krebs said the agency was in regular contact with Twitter and Facebook on the matter, although DHS efforts largely focused on security issues involving voting machines.

Here’s a look at how the top 10 races identified by the POLITICO Pro Tech team played out:

— Cruz rides to victory in Texas: Sen. Ted Cruz (R), who’s hammered the tech industry over alleged anti-conservative bias, beat back a challenge from Rep. Beto O'Rourke (D), who raked in a massive pile of donations from Silicon Valley.

“But with a tight window for legislating and the 2020 presidential election looming, the political climate doesn't favor robust cooperation, making any breakthroughs challenging.”

— Privacy politics: “The privacy debate has been brewing for months, fueled by disclosures about high-profile tech industry breaches,” he writes.

“But after capturing the House, Democrats will be eager to inject their own ideas into the mix.” Chief among those is empowering the Federal Trade Commission to craft new privacy rules and boosting the agency’s ability to impose fines — a proposal that could be a non-starter with leading Republicans.

— Blackburn bests Bredesen in Tennessee: Rep. Marsha Blackburn (R), who chairs the House Energy and Commerce tech subcommittee and has railed against social media firms, defeated Democrat Phil Bredesen in the election to fill the Senate seat being vacated by Republican Bob Corker.

— McCaskill toppled by Hawley in Missouri: Sen. Claire McCaskill (D), who championed an anti-sex trafficking bill opposed by tech companies, lost to Republican state Attorney General Josh Hawley, known for launching high-profile investigations of Facebook and Google.

— Rosen takes tech cred to the Hill: Rep. Jacky Rosen (D), a former computer programmer whose campaign drew substantial support from Silicon Valley, will become one of the few senators with a computer science background after defeating incumbent Dean Heller (R).

STATE SHAKE-UPS — Here’s how a few gubernatorial races we’re tracking panned out: Wisconsin’s Scott Walker, who pushed a multibillion dollar taxpayer-funded package to lure Taiwanese manufacturer Foxconn, lost his re-election bid against Democrat Tony Evers.

**

HOW TECH’S ALLIES AND ADVERSARIES FARED — Two of the tech sector’s harshest critics notched victories in hotly contested Senate races Tuesday, while several incumbent House lawmakers who allied with tech on trade and other issues went down in flames.

— And on House Intel, Rep. Adam Schiff: Schiff’s ascension will give him a bigger platform to scold internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter over foreign election interference and the persistent problems of trolls, bots and fake news.

Silicon Valley Must Reads

— Everything is awesome: Amazon’s quest to become the “everything company” appears to track with its reported plan to split its second headquarters between two locations, according to The New York Times.

— Merge madness: A trio of judges appointed by former Presidents Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama will hear the Justice Department appeal of a federal court’s approval of the AT&T-Time Warner merger, Reuters notes.

— Tech loses trade ally in Paulsen: Rep. Erik Philip Paulsen (R-Minn.), who’s championed the tech sector’s trade agenda on issues like cross-border data flows and liability protections, was ousted by Democrat Dean Phillips.

Foxconn is weighing whether to hire workers from China to staff its large facility in Wisconsin, where it struck a deal to hire and invest in the state in exchange for economic incentives, The Wall Street Journal reports.

Transitions

— Laura Peter, formerly deputy general counsel to A10 Networks in Silicon Valley, will serve as deputy director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross announced.

The two chambers “show signs that they could align around two issues: imposing privacy rules on the country’s tech giants and directing new funds to improve internet service in rural parts of the country,” John reports.

— GOP defector on net neutrality defeated: Rep. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.), who broke with his Republican colleagues to support the restoration of Obama-era net neutrality rules, went down in defeat to Democrat Jason Crow.

— Lance loses out in New Jersey: Rep. Leonard Lance (R), an advocate for freeing up more government-held spectrum for commercial use, got taken down by Democrat Tom Malinowski, a veteran of the Obama State Department.

“Commissioners and such may be testifying on a weekly basis and have to deal with aggressive congressional investigations,” said Robert McDowell, a former Republican FCC member who now advises wireless companies.

— Net neutrality returns: “Some House Democrats are intent on messaging legislation widely seen as doomed to fail in the Senate,” including an effort to restore the Obama-era net neutrality rules, John reports.

TECH’S BATTLE OVER HOMELESSNESS IN THE BAY — San Francisco approved a ballot initiative aimed at curbing homelessness, dealing a political blow to Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, who publicly opposed the measure.

Here’s what that would mean for key tech and telecom panels:

— On House E&C, we have Rep. Frank Pallone: Pallone wants to hold hearings and move legislation to revive the Obama-era net neutrality rules.
